 ALBANIA AGRO-PROCESSING DEVELOPMENT PROJECT CREDIT AND PROJECT SUMMARY Borrower: Government of Albania (GOA). Executing Agencies: Ministry of Agriculture and Food (MAF) and the Rural Commercial Bank (RCB). Beneficiaries: Private Agriculture Entrepreneurs, Farmers and Farmers' Associations. Credit Amount: SDR 4.1 million (US$6.0 million equivalent). Terms: Forty years with a ten year grace period, at standard IDA charge. Objectives: To support the development of the agro-processing sector and to help improve the conditions for financing its restructuring through the financial sector in order to improve marketing of farm outputs (thereby improving rural incomes) and availability of food products to the urban consumer. Description: The proposed project consists of Investment Credit and Entrepreneurs Support components. The Investment component would provide a line of credit for onlending by the RCB, at market rates, to the private agriculture enterprises, farmers and farmers associations for long-term (and permanent working capital) loans. The Entrepreneurs Support component would assist agro-processing enterprises but would focus on the dairy industry and would include relevant assistance to the RCB for the appraisal and supervision of sub-projects. The project would provide funds for experts and related expenses for: (i) long and short term experts in various fields; (ii) direct technical assistance and training/study tours to entrepreneurs (and their associations) in agro-processing, organization of private farmers associations, processing, quality assurance, management, marketing and other business aspects; and (iii) limited assistance to local institutions to strengthen their technical services and quality control law enforcement capabilities. Environmental Aspects: This project has been assigned a category "B" environmental rating. Although this rating indicates the possibility of specific environmental impacts with regards to discharges from agro-processing plants, the project is expected to result in an overall improvement in the environment. The Independent Lending Unit (ILU) of the RCB would review each sub-project for compliance with Albanian Environmental legislation and World Bank Environmental guidelines. During implementation, mechanisms would be established to monitor effluent standards. Benefits: The project would contribute several benefits to the Albanian economy. It would help restructuring of agro-processing enterprises. It is expected to help put into place a market access to farmers to sell milk and other farm products thereby reducing their wastage and encouraging improved farm production thus help increasing rural incomes. The urban consumers would benefit from the supplies of
 (ii) quality food products. It would make strides in institution-building and improving entrepreneurship and human capital through training and technical support. Since the dairy sector contributes as much as 10% to the nation's GDP the project could have a significant impact on the Albanian economy. Risks: The project would carry significant risks. Given weak institutional capacity, the implementation may be slow; this risk would be mitigated by the use of foreign experts with Albanian professionals by engaging an experienced foreign firm. The demand for processed products may be less; this risk is considered low given that processed products are still scarce in Albania so that a substantial part of the demand is not being met at present. The private entrepreneurs may be reluctant to borrow loans at market rates; discussions with private and public sector entities have revealed strong interest in loans as there is a shortage of long-term investment funds. The other major risk would be institutional capacity of the RCB to be able to service loans and monitor their performance; this risk is being addressed under the ASAC project through the provision of appropriate technical assistance to the ILU/RCB; the proposed project also includes technical assistance to the ILU. The ASAC and EFSAC projects are dealing with the issue of restructuring/privatization of the RCB. Other potential risk relates to the possibility of regional hostilities. Agricultural Situation 1.1 With almost two thirds of the Albanian population of 3.2 million residing in the rural areas, more than half of the total economically active population is employed in the agricultural sector. A large part of the industrial sector, which used to employ about 25 percent of the economically active population, concerned the food processing industry, which was largely dependent on the primary agricultural sector. This industry has completely collapsed since 1989. Due to the slow growth of employment in the industry and services sectors, in the past the policv of the Government was to retain surplus labor in the agricultural sector. 1.2 Before 1990, there were no private farmers, 75 percent of the rural population was dependent on cooperative farms for its living while the remaining 25 percent worked on state farms. With the collapse of the collective production system, the land and the cattle were divided amongst the workers of the cooperatives and state farms, and the rural families have become private farm families. Most of the land previously controlled by the cooperatives (75 percent of arable land) and state farms (25 percent of arable land) has been privatized, creating about 492,000 very small private farms each with 0.8 to 3.3 hectares of land (average 1.43 ha), the majority of which has one or two cows (Annex 1.1); some 30,000 rural families are without land. There is an overpopulation of farmers and thus large underemployment persists in the sector. 1.3 In the past, an important objective of the Government was the achievement of food self- sufficiency in the major staple crops. With input and output marketing controlled by the state, and prices and subsidies set by the state in a way that bore no relation to costs, huge inefficiencies in production were maintained. The result was self-sufficiency at a high cost. After the collapse of the centralized agricultural production system agricultural production first declined, the result of farmers inability to cultivate all fields during a fairly chaotic land distribution process. With land distribution almost complete, agricultural production is increasing, however, shortages of inputs and absence of adequate collection, marketing and processing systems remain serious constraints. While Albania is no longer dependent on food-aid imports, it is far from attaining its former status as a net food exporter. 1.4 Farmers Micro Environment. The newly privatized farmers are now focusing on subsistence farming, with some surplus available to the market, mainly to generate cash for the purchase of other essential commodities. Most farms produce both crop and other products, with wheat and maize still the main crops despite a marked shift in land use. Production of industrial crops has fallen, due to the inability to process crop products. Meat and milk are presently the main products sold through town markets. Wheat would also gain importance as an income source as production rises. Cattle and other livestock were distributed together with the land resulting in farmers consigning to fodder crop - mostly alfalfa - that portion of their land surplus to grain self-sufficiency requirement. Many farmers are now
 increasing their livestock holdings; however, feed supply remains a major constraint to improved livestock productivity. Farm fragmentation and the breakup of the mechanization network has led to some increase in the use of traction power. Farmers are finding it difficult to market products due to lack of adequate marketing and processing facilities. Annex 1.2 presents some key characteristics of the present small farmer production system in Albania. B. Livestock Production 1.5 Livestock is an important sector in the Albanian economy accounting for about half of the GDP added by the agricultural sector. The production of milk, mainly from cows, but also from sheep and goats, has always been the principal focus of livestock production, while meat was seen mainly as a by- product of the dairy sector. In 1989, milk accounted for 43 percent of the value of livestock products (of this 20 percent was from sheep and goats) and meat for 31 percent. Free market forces however, are likely to change this relationship where meat production represented between 38 and 48 percent of gross value of production. 1.6 In 1994, the cattle population was estimated at 743,500 head (Annex 1.3), of which 400,300 or 54 percent were milking cows as compared to 640,000 head in 1991, (306,000 milking cows), an increase of 16 percent. The rising level of breeding females in the national cattle herd also indicates the priority farmers give to milk production and suggests the early turnoff of progeny for meat, probably at sub- optimal weights. In 1992 cattle population was estimated at only 566,000 head (of which 324,000 milking cows). This initial fall in cattle numbers was probably the result of small holder capitalization through slaughter of stock acquired following the distribution of formerly cooperative-owned herds, combined with a particularly severe feed shortage during the 1991/92 winter. The strong growth thereafter was aided by a good summer fodder season in 1993 and a mild 1993/94 winter and the continuing control of most diseases. In 1994, the sheep population of 2.01 million included 1.48 million ewes (74%), and has already increased by more than 18 percent over the 1991 population, as has the goat population of some 1.39 million (up 16% over the 1991 level) which includes 1.01 million milking goats or 73 percent of the total population. The growing small ruminant population is likely the result of smallholder farmer access to previously under-utilized hill-side grazing. Meat, formerly produced in specialized industrial estates in the case of pigs and poultry, and food lots with cattle, is now mostly in the mixed smallholder farming sector with offtake at much lower ages and liveweights (12-18 months and 180-250 kg for cattle) due to the feed deficit. 1.7 Livestock is now entirely privately held. While most of the 492,000 private farms have livestock, the number per farm remains very small. According to the 1993 livestock statistics, 35 percent of the farms do not have a (milking) cow, 58 percent of the farms has one cow, while only 7 percent (representing about 27,000 farms) has more than one cow. The overall average of 0.73 cows per farm varies little between the plains (0.74) and the mountainous districts (0.70). Some 60 percent of all farms has at least one sheep and 45 percent at least one goat. The number of farms with more than 10 (adult female) sheep or goats is very limited, with 9 percent of the farms having more than 10 ewes and 8 percent with more than 10 milking goats. The milking sheep and goat population average of 4.80 per farm, varies from 4.04 in the plains to 6.29 per farm in the mountainous districts, reflecting the better access to natural pasture grazing lands in the uplands. Given the rate of growth in the sheep and goat populations - already over 10 percent since 1991 - the development of systems to sustainable exploit natural grazing lands would be critical to the development of the small ruminant sub-sector. The plains districts, including the coastal districts and Korca/Devoll, with 72 percent of the total population and 73 percent of the arable area, has 68 percent of the total number of milking cows, about 60 percent of the milking sheep and 50 percent of the milking goats.

Until the breakdown of the collective system, Government policy was to be self- supporting for both crop and livestock products, even with a rapidly increasing population. This has resulted in an increasing competition for land between food and feed production, resulting in shortages of roughage and animal feed. Livestock on the small private farms is now being better taken care of than the cattle on the cooperative farms in the past, as is reflected in the increasing average milk yields. Overall, the production of roughage has increased, while maize silage as the major feed for the winter season has been replaced by alfalfa hay (lucerne). Nevertheless, shortage of animal feed is still wide- spread, including a shortage of minerals. It is expected that the demand for concentrates would grow in the medium term, depending on the price ratio between milk and concentrate feed. In addition, some dairy by-products (whey and skim milk) could be used for animal feeding. There are 9 feed mills in Albania, each with a capacity of 3.5 tons per hour, all located in the plains districts. However, most feed mills are closed and those working producing only feed mixes for monogastric production. About 70 percent of the ingredients used are produced locally (mainly wheat and maize), the rest is imported (mainly soya, fish meal). There is a shortage of locally produced protein rich ingredients; by-products of the agricultural food processing industry are no longer available after the breakdown of this industry. To become operational again, the feed mills would require investment for rehabilitation and spare parts together with new technology such as feed pelleting. C. Agriculture Services 1.10 Extension Service. Each district now has a Department of Agriculture and Food with responsibilities in the areas of agricultural policy development at district level and the development of extension services in the communes. In each commune there is group of specialists, composed of an agronomist, a zoo technician, a veterinary inspector, an economist and a statistician, responsible for the collection of data from the farmers and for the delivery of extension services. Although a field service structure has thus been put in place at the district and commune levels, the actual delivery of extension
 - 4 - services yet need to be fully developed. The specialists gathered in the MAF field service have all been trained to work as specialists on large scale state and cooperative farms; they need to gain the experience and the general knowledge required to advise small farmers on how to improve production on a mixed farm and in a market economy. In this respect, the development of applied research required for the formulation of suitable extension messages is a priority area. In a number of pilot activities (e.g., the Netherlands supported project, "Agricultural Development in Fier District", and British assistance to the MAF) some first steps are presently being taken in defining small farmers' needs regarding technical advise and investigating adequate response to these needs. These projects focus on an integrated approach to farm development including simultaneous improvement of crop and livestock productivity (horizontal integration) and at the same time improvement of input supply and marketing of agricultural produce (vertical integration). 1.11 Agricultural Research. The agricultural research structure under the MAF consists of several Agricultural Research Institutes and Stations covering all major sub-sectors in agricultural production, including cereals, vegetables, livestock and forestry. This structure still requires major adjustments in order to be able to respond to the demands of the market economy and the present small farmer production situation. The institutes are generally poorly equipped and have insufficiently trained staff to cope with the required changes. There would most likely be a reduction in the number of institutes once a new research structure and programs have been defined. The institutes responsible for the development of food processing, enforcement of food quality control laws, etc., are the Institute of Veterinary Research (IVR), Institute of Public Health (IPH), Food Research Institute (IKU), and Agricultural and Food Design Institute (IPBU). The proposed project would support limited upgrading of the facilities of such institutions. 1.12 Veterinary Services. The Directorate of Veterinary Services presently employs some 400 permanent professional staff deployed at national, district and municipal level. With the Director and only three staff at the headquarters office - responsible respectively for veterinary services, inspection and epizootiological information - the service is heavily decentralized. Each district level MAF office has an Animal Health Sector, staffed by a complement of 3-4 veterinarians responsible for epizootiology and inspection of food and animal feed. In addition, a diagnostic veterinarian and a veterinary technician are employed in each of the 26 district veterinary laboratories which presently provide diagnostic services to the farmers without charge. This district team supports a cadre of veterinarians located at the 360 communes. At this level, veterinary staff are semi-private practitioners receiving a portion of their salary for the implementation of disease control and public health activities defined under the veterinary law: mainly vaccination and meat inspection. Animal treatment is on a fee basis for service and drugs. In Tirana, the Institute of Veterinary Research is the main academic institution dealing with veterinary services. 1.13 Artificial Insemination. The only field services actually responding directly to farmers' needs are the veterinary service and the artificial insemination (Al) service, operating at the village level. Farmers are also willing to pay for these services, but do complain about the cost. The Al service which presently operates with 285 private inseminators, urgently requires equipments (since long foreseen to be supplied with Italian aid) to function adequately at some 700 Al points and using frozen semen only. Al coverage has decreased from 70 percent in 1989 to less than 40 percent now. Semen doses are now Lek 60/straw and insemination charges range from Lek 150-300. The Italian authorities are considering a program to provide assistance for the strengthening of extension, veterinary and AI services.

Overview of the Sector 2.1 Albania's production of processed food expanded rapidly in the 1950's and 1960's as investments in the food processing industry grew and agricultural production and imports from the Former Soviet Union provided needed raw materials. In the 1970s the industry became more self-sufficient and experienced growth rates similar to agricultural production in the range of 2 to 12 percent for most products. In the early 1980s, production of key commodities such as bread fell below the population growth rate and the production of sugar and oil experienced negative annual growth rates of 8 and 2 percent respectively. During the second half of the decade, bread production kept just ahead of population growth, while sugar production stagnated and food oil production declined at an annual rate of 6 percent. By 1990, the Government's ability to produce bread, sugar and oils with domestic production fell significantly. The anticipated increased in bread, sugar and oil production also remain dependent upon the ability of the food processing enterprises to attract domestic production and survive without government financial support. 2.2 In the past, Albania's food policy was based on establishing at least one processing facility in each district for each subsector, ignoring economies of scale. The enterprises were only responsible for processing, as securing raw materials and marketing were handled by other state enterprises. The industry was directed by the Ministry of Food, which is now part of the Ministry of Agriculture and Food. Most of the technology is obsolete, as there has been almost no investment, even for necessary spares, for 20 years and only the creativity and skills of Albanian mechanical engineers have kept factories operating. Production efficiency and product quality are very low, and even minimum hygienic and sanitation standards are not met. 2.3 The agro-industrial sector includes about 200 large mostly state enterprises, about 400 private small scale dairies, about 100 private small scale sausage plants and several hundred rural bakeries. In 1993, the sector employed about 20,000 workers. Output fell dramatically after 1990. Most state food processing enterprises have been partially or totally closed since 1990/91. Some continue to operate at only a fraction of their capacity. Privatization of the plants is a first step towards revitalization of the industry, and this process needs to be expedited. There are several obstacles constraining the privatization process, one of which concerns the relatively high prices demanded for the existing buildings and installations, which in most cases are old, with outmoded production technologies. At the same time, potential buyers often consider the processing capacities of the existing plants too large, and generally prefer smaller processing units. To restart production, they need to organize the collection of sufficient quantities of inputs (milk, vegetables, fruits, meat, etc.), which is not an easy task considering the very small size of the many production units and farms. Further, packaging/bottling of the end products is often problematic due to a complete lack of the required materials and production facilities. In addition, marketing channels need to be developed for the sale of the end products. While there is quite substantial entrepreneurial interest in the agro-processing sector, several factors are hindering its development. These include: lack of adequate business management and marketing skills, lack of exposure to modern technology and operational techniques, lack of equity capital required by the banks for borrowing, and lack of credit and collateral property. The proposed project would address many of these constraints by providing training, advice and credit to private agricultural entrepreneurs. 2.4 The level of literacy in Albania is quite high and a large number of people were trained in skills in order to play a crucial role in the centrally controlled manufacturing system. However, there is a lack of exposure to modern industrial skills throughout the sector. Most of the personnel employed in the agro-processing industry are quire knowledgeable but lack comprehensive technical education. Some have
 - 6 - attended short courses after high school and learned the job through on-the-job training as there are no diploma courses in the field of agro-processing. This lack of modern technical skills shows in the poor processing and efficiency of operations. Given past heavily state controlled system, the management and business, (e.g., accounting, financial analysis, marketing, MIS, etc.) skills are lacking. There is a need to develop comprehensive training programs to upgrade basic technical, and management and business skills. In the beginning, some of this training should be offered at external institutions and by foreign experts in Albania. At the same time, steps should be taken to develop such capacity within Albania including development of short-term as well as diploma courses on various aspects of agro-processing sector. The proposed project would provide limited assistance to local technical institutions for developing such capability. B. Meat Processing 2.5 Most of the 28 state owned slaughter houses now operate at a much reduced level compared to 1991 and before, if operating at all. A significant number of cattle and small ruminants is now slaughtered on-farm without any veterinary control. Some meat on the hoof is also exported informally to Yugoslavia and to Greece. The state slaughter houses depend on the municipalities without central control from MAF. With the exception of those in Tirana, Vlore, Fier, Durres and Korca, the slaughter houses are very old with no investment in recent years; generally, they are completely obsolete. The specialized poultry slaughter house is now closed. Large scale poultry, egg and pig production has stopped entirely in 1991, as has beef fattening in the former central large scale feed lots. Meat production is now only on small scale private farm level, with rural village slaughters and consumption of the produced meat mainly in the rural areas. 2.6 Sausage production. The meat processing industry has been taken over by private entrepreneurs who have started their own small sausage production plants. There are presently over 100 small plants with a capacity ranging from 100-300 kg of sausage per day. There are also some larger industrial enterprises, including one in Tirana where with private Italian investment a factory with a capacity of 2,500-3,000 kg of sausage per day has been established. There is no government control on the estab- lishment and operation of the new plants. MAF is only globally aware of what is going on in this sector, and has no control, for example, on hygienic conditions, quality control, etc. Many of the new plants are operated by meat processing specialists who used to work in state meat processing enterprises. Only a few of the 14 state meat processing enterprises have been privatized. For most of the remaining state plants there is probably no future, even if they were to be privatized. Most of them can hardly be considered proper plants - their entire installations, cold storage rooms, etc. are defunct - only the build- ings remain, but these are generally old and not suitable for rehabilitation. The new meat processing plants operate predominantly using imported meat (Italian, Danish, etc.). A new plant requires modest investments in machinery and equipments for meat processing; the average investment in a new small plant is $8, - $10,000 for a meat mincing machine, a small packing machine and an autoclave. C. Flour Mills and Pasta Factories 2.7 Wheat production. The national production of wheat has again increased considerably after an initial drop following the distribution of land to the small private farms in 1991 and 1992/93. In 1990 wheat was cultivated on 203,000 ha of land, down to only 103,000 ha in 1992, but increasing to 170,000 ha in 1994. Wheat production decreased from 613,000 tons in 1990 to 252,000 tons in 1992 but increasing to 415,000 tons in 1994. The dry summer is not the only reason for the lower yields; also the lack of availability of irrigation, continuous cropping of wheat without rotation and a lower use of fertilizer and other inputs are contributing factors to decrease in yields. Farmers produce wheat primarily for their own needs; they store the required wheat at home and market only a small surplus, if available.
 It is estimated that not more than 20% of the produced wheat is marketed. Total national requirement of wheat is about 700,000 tons per year. To fill the gap between national production and requirement, 210,000 tons of food-aid wheat was imported in 1993 together with 88,000 ton of food-aid flour and 80,000 ton of commercial flour. Continued imports of wheat and flour will be necessary to fulfil the demand. 2.8 Flour mils. Albania's 42 flour mills have capacities ranging from 10 to 150 tons of wheat per day. The total (original) installed capacity of these mills is about 1,500 tons per day. The technical condition of most of the mills is very poor. Only three mills (Lushnje, Shkoder and Tirana) have reasonable installations, less than 15 years old. In a second mill in Tirana the Government has invested $1.5 million in German machinery in 1990; this is the only modern mill, with a processing capacity of 60 tons of wheat per day. Eleven of the mills have closed, while the remaining mills produce between 2 and 25 tons of flour per day for urban demand. Only 8 are privatized so far, while most of the other ones are in the process of privatization. Twenty-four of the 42 mills have reasonable to good quality buildings and could (from this point of view) qualify for rehabilitation, with investment in new technical installations. However, the total required milling capacity is now much lower than before. 2.9 Total flour production in the 42 large (state) mills was 320,000 tons in 1992, down to 136,000 tons in 1994. Food-aid has permitted the mills to continue to supply urban bakeries, although they were unable to meet the demand from the several hundred rural bakeries. V. PROPOSED PROJECT A. Project Objectives 5.1 The main objective of the proposed project is to support the development of the agro-processing sector in Albania and to help improve the conditions for financing its restructuring through the financial sector in order to improve marketing of farm outputs (thereby improving rural incomes) and availability of food products to urban population. B. Project Justification and Scope 5.2 In the agro-processing sector, the proposed project would support an integrated private sector approach in which the entire marketing chain, i.e., collection, processing and distribution of the products is tackled. Consistent with the strategy outlined in a joint World Bank and European Commission document (and adopted by the Government), entitled, "An Agricultural Strategy for Albania", October 1992, the proposed approach would be to make maximum utilization of existing assets whenever economically feasible, with appropriate investments in renovation of existing plants including some new equipment (e.g., packing units), as well as establishment of small new processing plants in rural and urban areas. A substantial amount of training and technical support would be provided to upgrade skills and to improve management and business practices, as well as to strengthen local institutional capacity. 5.3 In the absence of project supported activities the marketing constraints in Albania would become even more acute, preventing farm production increases resulting from improved irrigation and other factors, and limiting the farm surplus made available for sale. There is already evidence of milk and other farm products being wasted because of lack of marketing and processing facilities and the situation is likely to get worse without the project. In the absence of improved marketing and processing facilities, the farmers would be forced to limit their production to subsistence levels only thereby contributing to continued shortages of milk and other processed products to the urban population. It is quite evident from ongoing experience that the project is needed to "make things happen". Since the prices of agriculture products in Albania are liberalized and interest rates are market determined there are no prevailing distortions in the market which are likely to hamper project effectiveness. 5.4 Design Considerations. The project has been designed with the objective of putting a minimum burden on the government budget and to sustain itself in the long run without continuing government support. In arriving at the proposed project design several alternatives were considered. For the Entrepreneurs Support activities use of existing MAF department, setting up a new government body or a totally private foundation were evaluated with the involvement of relevant public and private officials.
 - 19 - It was decided that establishment of a Technical Services Unit with foreign and local expertise with minimum government involvement which would evolve into a totally private sector operation, would be most appropriate option. Given the importance of the agro-processing sector in the Albanian economy, the need for substantial assistance, lack of private sector alternatives, and low paying capacity of emerging entrepreneurs, the initial public investment in technical assistance is well justified for a period of 2-3 years. In the long run, such activity is expected to be taken over by the private sector. For the line of credit, the Government had desired a targeted line reserved exclusively for the dairy sector. However, due to its potential adverse distortionary impact on resource allocation, it was decided to open the credit line to the entire agriculture sector. For the financing channel, as described earlier, there are no well developed banking institutions in Albania and it would take several years before any well functioning bank is expected to emerge. However, the pressing long-term resource needs of the agriculture sector need to be met. Any delay (until the emergence of good banks) in making these resources available would be very detrimental to the sector so important to the Albanian economy. To achieve this purpose, several alternatives were considered. Establishment of a separate specialized institution at this stage would not be cost effective and in the long run would be counter productive. Continuing with the agency arrangements used successfully under the ASAC were also not considered desirable as the GOA should not continue to carry the credit risk. Rather the RCB as a banking institution should be fully responsible for lending at its own risk. It is also recognized that based on the strict application of OD 8.30 criteria, the RCB would not to be eligible to borrow funds on its own due to its weak financial condition. However, RCB's condition is expected to improve in the future, and with IDA assistance the Government is aggressively pursuing a restructuring/privatization plan for the RCB. Therefore, it is proposed to onlend funds through the RCB to service the agriculture sector with RCB taking full risk. C. Impact on Women 5.15 The proposed project is expected to have a positive impact on the women. In Albania, women take primary responsibility for the management of ruminant stock and, dependent on the scale of the operation, frequently take charge of the production and marketing of dairy products. Where women are involved in farm products especially fruits, vegetables and milk marketing, the task may involve a bus trip to town and the commitment of up to a half day to sell small quantities of products. Income thus derived is frequently retained by women for household expenses though any balance is likely to be submitted to the male household head on a regular basis and expenditure accounted for. While, agro- products production, processing and marketing may afford women some control over the household budget, it is a time consuming addition to the already onerous life of the female smallholder farmer. Improved access to markets for agro-products should give relief to women in perhaps the most time consuming tasks of one of the major activities at the farm, while at the same time providing regular household income. The stimulation of private farmers associations would provide improved access to input supplies and technical information with consequent impact on farm productivity and household income. Credit for which women would be eligible, could permit access to more animals or investment in small-scale processing, capturing traditional skills frequently held by women to add value to farm products.

Milk production alone generates about 20 percent of the value of agricultural GDP, while associated ruminant meat production accounts for a further 8-12 per cent making ruminant production the single most important activity in the rural sector and frequently the primary source of cash income for the farm family. With an estimated over 60 percent of surplus milk, and other farm products now unable to find a market, the revitalization of the agro-processing industry could have a significant impact on smallholder farm family income. In monetary terms, a 10 percent increase in marketed milk from the statistically average farm of 1.66 ha carrying 0.77 cows and producing 1,250 liters of milk would raise family cash income by 2,250 Lek, an amount equivalent to a months wage as an agricultural laborer. As farmer confidence in the economic recovery improves and the farm family self-sufficiency mentality declines it is likely that a further 10 to 15 percent of production could be made available to the market. Access to a reliable market outlet would ensure a regular cash income from dairy and other farm products sales, a factor that frequently leads to higher and more timely investment in other agricultural production activities, and is likely to stimulate increased investment in farm production, with most of such incremental product marketed. Although the project components do not contain specific mechanisms for targeting the least well off, it is expected, given the nature of the project and its components that the population of project beneficiaries would have a larger proportion of poor people than the population as a whole. In Albania, farmers are generally poor with very small farms and only I to 3 animals. The project is expected to benefit them most although indirectly through improved marketability of farm products. Therefore, the project would be rated as "Poverty Category: Program for Targeted Interventions" in accordance with the provisions of OD 4.15. H. As stated above, it is expected to help improve rural incomes by putting in place a market access to farmers to sell their surplus farm products such as fruits, vegetables, meat and milk thereby reducing their wastage and generating regular cash. Milk provides a daily cash flow throughout the year without excessive borrowing and as such empowers women. It tempers some of the seasonality in cash availability in rural areas which could lead to poverty reduction as well as an overall better diet in rural and urban areas. Access to markets would also result in improved farm production. The urban consumer would receive supply of quality processed food products. It would make strides in institution-building improving private entrepreneurship and human capital through training, technical education and advice. Organization of PFAs would have several indirect benefits, e.g., system to supply farm inputs, better product handling techniques, pooling of supplies for better markets. Improvements in the quality control system would also have a positive impact on food production and nutritional intake. Application of project evaluation techniques including financial rate of return would ensure that only commercially viable investments are supported; all sub- projects would have at least 12% rate of return in real terms. Since the democratic revolution in 1991, the supply of financial services by the formal banking sector is constrained by a general inability of banks to respond to a growing credit demand by the new private sector. Bankers under the centrally-planned economy were mere bookkeepers, transferring budget funds to state enterprises. There were no hard budget constraints and therefore no need to assess borrowers' creditworthiness and ability to repay a loan. Banks now face the need for radical change as they convert themselves into independent decision-makers involved in all aspects of financial intermediation. Staff training and outside technical assistance for state-owned banks, as well as the establishment of new private banks with strong foreign partners, are both required in order to close the gap between the previous centrally-controlled banking system and a system of efficient financial intermediation in a free-enterprise regime. 2. Creation of State Banks. The emergence of commercial banking institutions, as separate legal entities with a customer base and staff separate from the Central Bank, is a very recent phenomenon in Albania. Based on Law No. 7491 of April 29, 1991 on the "Main Constitutional Provisions", the State Bank of Albania (later transformed into the Bank of Albania (BOA), the Central Bank) was sub-divided into four banks: the National Bank, the Albanian Commercial Bank, the Savings Bank (SB), and the Bank for Agriculture and Development (BAD). Each of these banks were created through individual laws. In January of 1993, the National Bank and the Albanian Commercial Bank were merged into the National Commercial Bank (NCB). Under the IDA-supported Agriculture Sector Adjustment Credit (ASAC, FY93), BAD was split into the Rural Commercial Bank (RCB) and the BAD in Liquidation, as of October 1, 1993. RCB received the mandate to complete the liquidation of the BAD. The Ministry of Finance (MOF) owns the capital and exercises management control over all state-owned commercial banks. See Table I for an overview of the Albanian banking sector. 3. Private Banks. Since 1993, a number of small private banks have been created in the form of joint- ventures with foreign partners, including the Albanian-Italian Bank, the Arab Albanian Islamic Bank (AAIB), and the Dardania Bank (DB). These banks are slowly building up their capacities to mobilize household deposits and to lend to few selected credit customers, but as yet they play no major role providing investment finance for agricultural and other rural activities. New bank licensing regulations were issued in June 1995 to facilitate the entry of further new private banks, and some 20 applications have been received since then by BOA. An initiative by the German KfW aims at creating a lending institution for small- and medium-scale enterprises by end-1995. The new Albanian-American Enterprise Fund is also expected to start lending activities for small and medium sized businesses, as well as equity participation and possibly guarantee operations, by early 1996. Overall financial and banking sector development, including specific regulatory measures in the banking sector, are supported under the Bank- financed Enterprise and Financial Sector Adjustment Credit (EFSAC, FY94).

D. Outlook 37. Need for Restructuring. After a period of rather successful initial institutional restructuring of the bank, facilitated by outside technical assistance, RCB is now in need of financial restructuring, combined with privatization, if the bank is to become a viable rural financial institution. The bank's cash-flow gap can only be overcome through a replacement of non-interest bearing assets through productive and secure assets. Furthermore, substantial improvements in the bank's internal work organization, credit operations, accounting and financial management, and general efficiency and service quality are unlikely to occur unless strong governance through a private, qualified banking institution can be established. 38. Financial Restructuring. Regarding financial restructuring, there are two main options to reduce required loan loss provisions and improve the bank's interest income and cash-flow, both of which imply a recapitalization of RCB through cash or interest-bearing bonds, the main source of which would likely be the public budget. A first option would be to relieve the bank of the loan portfolio of its 10 worst performing branches. This would reduce required loss provisions by about Lek 1.2 billion (including Lek 800 million in principal and Lek 400 million against interest); and it would reduce (eliminate) the cash- flow deficit by about Lek 200 million per year, resulting in positive net interest revenues. A second option would be to relieve the bank from most or all of its pre-October 1993 loans, most of which
 - 51 - Annex 4.2 Page 13 of 14 represent unrecoverable truck and tractor loans described above. The related benefit would be a reduction of loss provisions by about Lek 1.5 billion and an improvement in cash-flow by Lek 270 per year. Either solution would result in positive capital and positive annual cash-flows, making the bank viable based on the observed improvements in loan collections and assuming a complete halt of new lending in all but the best performing 10 branches. The estimated net cost to the budget, through issuance of bonds and/or provision of cash, would be in the order of Lek I billion to Lek 1.5 billion (US$1l to 17 million). 39. In addition to recapitalization, the Government has further ways to improve RCB's financial situation. First, the BAD-related loan by RCB, guaranteed by the Government, could be made current through payment by MOF of accrued interested estimated at about Lek 600 million, and possibly repayment of the principal of Lek 566 million. Both actions together, and by themselves, would likely result in the restoration of positive capital. Furthermore, Government could adequately remunerate RCB for its services as an agent that is making pension and other public payments to residents in rural areas. Alternatively, if Government decided to terminate RCB's agent function, the bank could close most of those agencies that are not net contributors to RCB's bottom line. 40. Privatization. However, financial restructuring alone, without parallel privatization, would bear the risk of continued unsatisfactory governance and possible future losses due to politically motivated lending. Also, as a public institution, the bank could not expect to obtain further substantial amounts of government-funded technical assistance, hence reducing substantially prospects for further improvements in operational efficiency. Government and BOA are, therefore, supporting the notion of bank privatization which, in the case of RCB, would require a strong, committed and reputable private banking institution as an investor, able to provide qualified management and technical expertise from its own resources. Since no such institution can be identified within the country today, a foreign strategic investor in the banking industry would be the most desirable new owner of a privatized RCB. Various methods of bank privatization for the state-owned banks are in the discussion, and it is expected that a decision on the method and timing of RCB privatization would be made before the end of 1995. 41. ILU Operations. Since its establishment in early 1994, the operations of the ILU regarding on- lending of ASAC funds to rural borrowers are judged to be working rather well, especially when compared to other banking institutions and donor credit windows in the country. The ILU has largely fulfilled its objective of becoming a model for an efficient rural banking window within RCB, and ILU's credit evaluation standards and operational procedures became the basis for revising RCB's Credit Manual and the bank's overall credit management. If RCB was to be privatized, the ILU could remain a part of the bank. Alternatively, if RCB was to be downsized and possibly merged with another bank, the ILU could be transferred to this new bank as well.

doc.abstracts: The main objective of the Agro-Processing Development Project is to support the development of the agro-processing sector in Albania and to help improve the conditions for financing its restructuring through the financial sector in order to improve marketing of farms outputs (thereby improving rural incomes) and availability of food products to urban population. The project has two main components: 1) an entrepreneurs support component which includes technical assistance, equipment and vehicles, and training and study tours; and 2) an investment credit component.
